title: 103_hr3735
content: Emergency supplemental appropriations for disaster assistance, including the Small Business Administration's disaster loans program account, are provided for the Los Angeles Earthquake in fiscal year 1994. Emergency supplemental appropriations of $163,405,000 are allocated for emergency expenses following the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California and other disasters. Up to $35,000,000 can be used for administrative expenses. The entire amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The Department of Education is allocated $165,000,000 for disaster assistance activities following the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California and other disasters. The funds are designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. An additional $80,000,000 is allocated for student financial assistance under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The funds can be reallocated for individuals affected by the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The Federal Highway Administration oversees the Federal-Aid Highways program, including the emergency relief program funded by the highway trust fund. The Emergency Fund authorized by 23 U.S.C. 125, totaling $950,000,000 for expenses related to the 1994 earthquake in Southern California and other disasters. An additional $400,000,000 is available upon official budget request approval, sourced from the Highway Trust Fund and remaining available until expended. Congress must designate the entire amount as an emergency requirement. The limitation on obligations per State in 23 U.S.C. 125(b) does not apply to earthquake-related projects. The Federal share for earthquake-related projects on the Federal-aid highway system shall be 100 percent for costs incurred in the 180-day period after the earthquake. The Secretary and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency may waive or modify environmental regulations to facilitate the use of funds for these projects. In response to the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California, the Department of Veterans Affairs is allocated an additional $21,000,000 for emergency medical care expenses. This funding is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The Department of Housing and Urban Development focuses on housing programs. Housing Programs - annual contributions for assisted housing $150,000,000 allocated for rental assistance under section 8 housing programs, to replenish headquarters reserve for earthquake victims in Southern California. Secretary may waive statutes or regulations in fund administration. The Secretary may waive statutes or regulations in fund administration, excluding requirements related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, environment, and labor standards, if necessary to facilitate fund use. The entire amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The Secretary may waive statutes or regulations in fund administration to facilitate fund use, excluding certain requirements. $100,000,000 is allocated for emergency assistance to owners of eligible multifamily housing projects damaged by the 1994 earthquake in Southern California. Assistance is available until September 30, 1995, for repair purposes. Assistance can be provided to owners not insured under the National Housing Act if certain conditions are met. Emergency assistance of $100,000,000 is allocated for repairing damage or recovering losses from the 1994 Southern California earthquake. The entire amount is designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The FHA general and special risk program account is mentioned. Title II of the National Housing Act is amended to provide higher mortgage limits and improved access to mortgage insurance for disaster victims. This includes changes to section 203(h) related to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Secretary is authorized to insure single-family residences in disaster-declared areas for a temporary period not exceeding 18 months. The Secretary is authorized, for a temporary period not to exceed 18 months from the date of a Presidential declaration of a major disaster, to enter into agreements to insure mortgages and rehabilitation loans for disaster victims. The Secretary can insure mortgages and rehabilitation loans for disaster victims for up to 18 months after a Presidential disaster declaration. Loans must meet specific requirements and be in a designated disaster area. Community Planning and Development offers community development grants. $250,000,000 is allocated for community development grants for emergency expenses from the 1994 earthquake in Southern California. The funds are available until September 30, 1996, for eligible activities under title I, excluding those reimbursable by FEMA or available through SBA. Up to $50,000,000 can be transferred to the HOME investment partnerships program for eligible activities under title II. The $250,000,000 allocated for community development grants for emergency expenses from the 1994 earthquake in Southern California must be used to replenish amounts previously obligated under the Community Development Block Grant or HOME programs. The Secretary has the authority to waive certain requirements to facilitate the use of these funds, except for statutory requirements related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, the environment, and labor standards. The entire amount designated by Congress as an emergency requirement under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 must be used for specified purposes. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is allocated $3,484,000,000 for disaster relief, including the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California. The funds are designated by Congress as an emergency requirement and will remain available until expended. The additional $15,000,000 allocated for Emergency Management Planning and Assistance is designated by Congress as an emergency requirement to study the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California for enhancing seismic safety throughout the United States. An additional $400,000,000 is allocated for emergency expenses related to the January 1994 earthquake in Southern California and other disasters. The funds can be transferred to any authorized Federal governmental activity to meet disaster requirements, subject to an official budget request and congressional approval. GENERAL PROVISIONS: Appropriations in this Act must be used within the current fiscal year unless specified otherwise. The Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Disaster Assistance Because of the Los Angeles Earthquake Act of 1994 allows for the transfer of funds within the Federal Buildings Fund to cover emergency expenses from the 1994 earthquake in Southern California. The Act ensures that no operating activity or capital project is reduced by more than five percent.
